newsitem.title: FRANCE: Jospin faces union test on Europe, pay, sell-offs.
newsitem.headline: Jospin faces union test on Europe, pay, sell-offs.

text.p: New French Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, having promised a break with obsessive economic austerity and an accountant's view of Europe, is under considerable trade union pressure to deliver.
Socialist Jospin can probably count on a warmer start to relations than the previous government.

But union leaders are already seeking wage rises, a rethink on privatisation and reassurances that he will stop turning the screws on public spending in the name of European economic and monetary union (EMU).

One high-profile national union leader, Force Ouvriere (FO) chief Marc Blondel, says his most urgent priority is getting Jospin to confirm that France will push for a less stringent qualification test for the single euro currency.

Blondel wants to avoid more public spending cutbacks that would hit the social security system. He also dislikes the "stability pact" on the control of budget deficits in the wake of the planned 1999 EMU launch.

Even if Blondel is fighting a personal campaign on the social security front, his desire to keep Jospin to his word of a shift in emphasis on EMU is shared by others, including the more moderate white-collar CGC union.
CGC chief Marc Vilbenoit says monetary union needs more of a social dimension and less obsession with curbing public deficits to precisely three percent of gross domestic product (GDP).

Several union leaders have made it clear they are not under any illusion about the prospects for rapid progress on Socialist promises of 700,000 jobs and a move to a shorter 35-hour working week within three years.
More pressing issues will be the SMIC national minimum wage, civil service wage increases and privatisations planned by the centre-right before it lost Sunday's parliamentary election.
The Communist-led CGT union has demanded an immediate rise in the minimum wage beyond the automatic indexed increase which takes place in July.
The Communist Party has the same line and will get some posts in the Socialist-dominated coalition but is not expected to have the muscle to hold Jospin hostage.
Socialist Elizabeth Guigou has said her party wants to give the minimum wage a lift from 37.91 francs ($6.50) per hour, or 6,406.79 francs a month, currently.
Blondel's Force Ouvriere argues that SMIC-earners in textiles and other low-wage sectors get relief on social security charges and that boosting the SMIC could at best exacerbate this problem.

Civil service pay is another nettle that Jospin's team will have to grasp after universal union rejection in February of a 2.8 percent pay rise over 1997-98 which was imposed by former civil service minister Dominique Perben.
Nicole Notat, leader of the large CFDT union, listed civil service pay among her main concerns when spelling out what she expected of the new government earlier this week.
Unions are still looking for a "catch-up" offer after a pay freeze in 1996, although they failed to muster strong support for a one-day strike after February's unilateral increase.
The picture becomes a bit more clouded on the question of privatisation. Firstly, the government has yet to make its own position clear on a string of sell-offs planned by the previous government.
Most urgent is the planned sale of a minority stake in France Telecom, which was initially supposed to be launched in July.
That was due to be followed by the sale of a 58-percent stake in defence electronics firm Thomson-CSF and the sell-off of the CIC bank and parent insurance company GAN.

Of the large unions, the only one categorically opposed to all privatisation is the Communist-led CGT, while the CFDT, FO and the Catholic CFTC have all said this week they are not hostile to opening up the telecoms operator's capital to private investors.
The outlook gets more muddled for the rest, where union objections at company level may be stronger than the principles laid down at national headquarters.
This, too, could prove to be the case for other privatisation plans that were less advanced, such as the sale of state bank Credit Lyonnais and Air France UTAF.PA. ($ = 5.837 French Francs)
